fields.description: Now we need to press Refresh in browser to see new comments, builds, updates, etc on pull request page. Will be nice to have it automatically.
fields.summary: Live update of pull request page

fields.description:
I can add a user to a branch permission even if that user does not have repo access. I think this should not be possible, to try to avoid confusion.

In the same way it rejects users that are not licensed, it should also reject users that don't have repo perms. Helps to avoid confusion.
fields.summary: Adding a user to a branch permission should not be allowed if user has no access through branch or repo permissions

fields.description:
In Crucible we have set up default reviewers for our Reviews, which saves a lot of time. Crucible can also suggest reviewers based on contributors to a repository. 

It would be great to get either of those features into Stash.
fields.summary: Set default reviewers for Pull Request from contributors or per-Project list

fields.description:
Example: try to find the unified admin project by typing in "Unified Admin", and observe zero results.

But when I add a trailing forward slash, I get the result I'm after!

This is definitely not intuitive behaviour for a searchbox; I would expect it to preference repositories but show projects too for any plain text search (after all the repositories), and then perhaps switch to the "project / repo name" approach when there's a slash that has been typed.
fields.summary: When I'm searching for an organization, I shouldn't have to type / before getting results

fields.description:
Currently you must be scrolled down into 'full screen mode' before you see a horizontal scrollbar.

Add a widget to display a scrollbar fixed at the bottom of the window, even when not scrolled all the way to the bottom.
fields.summary: Show horizontal scrollbar in diffs when not scrolled to bottom
page layout on monitors in portrait orientation

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

* Navigate to a changeset via /commits/30e07f77ab9ee6cb62dd92f016db4f6433b1beb9
* Click on a link to navigate to parent commit on right hand side
* Current url is /commits/689684ad229b5f1a6491fc2501a25c4fb8489c88
* Click on Files tab

Expected:
* /browse?at=689684ad229b5f1a6491fc2501a25c4fb8489c88

Actual:
* /browse?at=30e07f77ab9ee6cb62dd92f016db4f6433b1beb9
fields.summary: Navigation to parent commit's files is not working properly

fields.description:
Not sure how new the pull request screen, but just looking at it now it's very nice. Love the sidebar feature.

Keep it going!
fields.summary: Love the new pull request screen

fields.description:
Tried to merge, it failed due to poor mobile connection.

Clicked merge again. The dialog popped up, with the Merge button disabled from the original attempt and a spinner going.

A page reload works around it.
fields.summary: Bug - if merge fails you can't merge again without page reload.

fields.description:
I'm looking for a merge strategy that can both force fast-forward only merges, yet still produce a merge commit.  The reason this is useful is to ensure linear history with a rebase workflow (the --ff-only) and yet still reflect the existence and grouped commits from the pull request (the --no-ff).

See a solution here:

  https://stackoverflow.com/questions/15631890/how-to-achieve-git-no-ff-ff-only-which-is-not-allowed
fields.summary: Add merge strategy for Pull Requests that does --no-ff and --ff-only

fields.description:
Using Chrome Version 34.0.1847.131 m, I have noticed that although comment permalinks highlight the comment in question (in a very pleasant light blue), the page is not scrolled at all.  So, if I have a comment that is further down the Overview page, it can be tricky to spot the comment whilst scrolling.

It would be nice if the page would scroll to show the comment in view on browsing of the permalink (ala URLs specifying HTML bookmark/href anchors)
fields.summary: Pull Request comment Permalinks should scroll the browser to show the comment in view
Pull Request comment permalinks on Diff tab should take you to Diff tab not Overview tab

fields.description:
We have currently one main Git repository that uses the SVN Mirror plugin to sync the Git repo with SVN. Furthermore, we created a fork of that Git repository, where we allowed Fork Syncing. 
However, Fork syncing doesn't seem to work, because the forked repo is never updated. When I go to the forked repo and disable and then enable fork syncing again, then the fork is synced.
I dont want to go to the fork and always manually reenable fork syncing because we have many forked repositories!
fields.summary: Fork Syncing not working when SVN Mirror Plugin is used

fields.description:
Background:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/275306/xsrf-errors-in-repo-creation-using-custom-httpauthenticationhandler reports running into problems while writing a custom HTTP auth plugin for Kerberos / SPNEGO. If the browser cannot participate in the auth negotiation, a Basic auth challenge is sent by the auth_krb_auth apache module. 

When Basic auth credentials are provided, Stash always authenticates the request - even if the user was already authenticated. Because of the session fixation protection, a new session is created for every such request (and the old session is invalidated). Browsers can send multiple requests in parallel, which can lead to session invalidation races. The result is that the session fixation protection code won't always be able to copy the session data to the new session and the xsrf token is lost.

Instead of re-authenticating every request, authentication should only be attempted if the user is not already authenticated.
fields.summary: Basic authentication in the web UI leads to XSRF errors

fields.description:
When a merge request check calls com.atlassian.stash.scm.pull.MergeRequest#veto - the detailedMessage is shown in a hover in the UI. 

If there are multiple merge request checks, and more than one veto, hovering over the Merge button shows "this pull request can't be merged automatically" (hovering over the (!) shows the first veto message, but the Merge button text never changes - and is wrong in many cases).
fields.summary: "cannot merge" error message not useful if multiple merge requests veto
Create PR screen shouldn't suggest you as a reviewer

fields.description: The navlinks plugin contains a Google Analytics key. The profile that is attached to this key was deleted a while ago and we don't include the {{ga.js}} script in Stash so no analytics events will be send. We should still get rid of the remaining code.
fields.summary: Navlinks contains Google Analytics tag and key
Cannot link Stash to JIRA
Restore merge activity for pull requests

fields.description:
STASH-4517 introduced a recurring background job that deletes empty rescope activities. Unfortunately, this delete query performs very poorly on MySQL when there are lots of records in the sta_activity_* tables. This can result in both an increase in deadlocks and extremely long delays on other SQL operations.

Another action which can trigger these slow operations is deleting a repository, since that requires deleting all of the repository's pull requests (and their activities).
fields.summary: Performance empty pull request rescope activities is very poor on MySQL
ContextualFormFragment#validate is never called for fork repository dialog

fields.description:
Although the [Stash Git protocol support plugin|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.stash.plugin.stash-git-anonymous-protocol-plugin] lists 2.12.1 and 2.12.3 as supported versions, when the plugin is installed, the *Administration > Server Settings* page fails to render and returns {{Failed to render stash.gitServer.admin.fragment}} with an 500 error code.

*Workaround*
Disable the plugin while changing {{Server Settings}}.
fields.summary: Stash Git protocol support plugin fails to render Server Settings page

fields.description: When using http://interrobeng.com/2013/08/25/speed-up-git-5x-to-50x/ SSH can get into a situation where the sessions aren't correctly timed out. This causes a memory leak and can cause an OOME
fields.summary: Memory leak when using a persistent SSH connections

fields.description: Would be feasible to have the ability to disable the auto merge operations for certain branches in order to have better merge control.
fields.summary: As a user, I would like to have the ability to disable auto merge operations for certain branches

fields.description:
The following results in an OOME in Stash (please don't do this on our production instances)

{code}
```result.toEither.left.foreach{ case .... }```

or 

```result.swap.foreach{ case ... } // foreach is only defined on the right side of validation```
{code}

Looks like if you replace {{```}} with {{`}} it works fine.

We will need to fix this in Pegdown.

https://github.com/sirthias/pegdown/issues/127

fields.description:
When we upgraded from 2.11 to 2.12, stash stopped remembering that I like to view diffs in side-by-side mode. Now every time I visit a pull request I have to type "shift D" to switch to side-by-side mode. Not a huge deal, but enough of an annoyance that I'd like to see it fixed.

To reproduce:

1. View a PR in side-by-side diff mode.
2. Copy URL, paste into a new tab.
3. PR is show back in normal diff mode.
fields.summary: Stash should remember side-by-side diff preference

fields.description: We recently renamed a JIRA project, which changed the URL for each of that project's cases. If we type an old URL in to the address bar the browser redirects correctly to the new page for that case. However, when clicking the link to a case in the corresponding Stash commit log an HTML "dialog" appears stating that it "Can't display issues".
fields.summary: Renamed JIRA cases cannot be displayed in the Stash commit list

fields.description:
In the following directory structure:

* Directory 1
** user 'bob'
* Directory 2
** user 'bob'

directory 2 user 'bob' is shadowed by directory 1 user 'bob' and is hidden. If you rename directory 2 user 'bob' to 'robert' it is a logical creation of user 'robert' but stash incorrectly renames the 'bob' stash user to be 'robert' and crreates a new 'bob' stash user.
fields.summary: Renaming a shadowed user incorrectly renames the associated stash user

fields.description: From the documentation I have learned that I can create a plugin which can veto any merges. The problem is that its called on all events related to pullRequest, is there any way I can get hold of an event that is triggered on PullRequestCreation ?
fields.summary: PullRequest Creation event

fields.description: Merges and pull requests by default re-use the same commit messages, which is great, but smart commits get re-applied doubling, tripling, etc. the time taken and filling the comments with multiple instances of the same comment.  This makes the smart commit feature useless.
fields.summary: Remove smart commits from pull requests/merges

fields.description: Currently, the PR Overview tab will only show the comments activities for the 'Diff' only. Would be feasible, if it can include the comments activity for commits (the commits in the PR) as well.
fields.summary: As a user, I would like to see the commits comments activity on the PR Overview

fields.description: Hi - it'd be very useful if pull request commit comments featured in the overview page - both in the activity feed and/or some open comments list.  Currently it seems onerous to manually go through each file of each commit looking for the comments.  Easy to miss one.
fields.summary: Summary of pull request commit comments in overview tab/activity feed

fields.description:
We've discovered a code bug that *may* be causing users who have checked "Remember me" to still be forced to log in whenever their session expires (default is after about 30 min of inactivity), rather than having their session automatically extended. This effect is so far hypothetical - it's not confirmed in practice yet.

The bug would affect Stash instances that having been running long enough for 500 user session invalidations to occur on the instance, and restarting the Stash server would reset this back to 0.

You may see a CookieTheftException in the logs when a user is forced to log in.
fields.summary: "Remember-me" users forced to log in too often

fields.description: There is nothing to see here.  This is a test issue for ADM-53678.
fields.summary: Bplump Test Issue

fields.description:
We can improve the experience for authentication handler plugin devs (like in https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/275306/xsrf-errors-in-repo-creation-using-custom-httpauthenticationhandler) by doing a couple of things:

# Add info to https://developer.atlassian.com/stash/docs/latest/reference/plugin-module-types/http-authentication-handler.html about the authentication "workflow" in Stash, and the various cookies we use (JSESSIONID, _atl_remember_me, _atl_token, ...) and how they play into into that workflow. This will help plugin devs in debugging when their handler doesn't quite work.
# Add more debug logging around session creation and invalidation, if possible.
fields.summary: Improve AuthenticationHanlder plugin dev debugging experience

fields.description: If a user is connected to multiple user directories simultaneously (internal one included), and renames an LDAP user such that its username is identical to an existing Stash user, an exception is thrown and user synchronisation fails.
fields.summary: User unable to sync LDAP/Active Directory after user rename if username already exists in another directory

fields.description:
I see there is lot of work done to create stash-test-infrastructure and I would like to use that so I can test my plugin with each new update. I have plugins for "PreReceiveRepositoryHook" & "RepositoryMergeRequestCheck" and would like to create some tests where I can simulate different types of commits/pull-requests with & without enabling the plugins. 

I would really appreciate if you can provide some examples or documentation from where I can learn that - thanks
fields.summary: Documentation how to use Stash Test Infrastructure

fields.description: When I merge a pull request I'd like to be able to iteratively merge to newer release branches by way of a pull request (instead of an automatic merge) so that I can check build results first.
fields.summary: Semi-automatic cascading merges via pull requests

fields.description: This would be really nice for reviewing Java codebases (especially where maven is involved), since the file names are long and the directory trees are deep.
fields.summary: Feature request: Ability to resize the "Changed files" sidebar

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce the bug:

- Go to Administration cog icon >> User Directories >> Add Directory (button) >> Choose JIRA and Next
- On the form, add the right parameters and configure click the Test button. This gives you a "Success" message.
- Now, before you click the "Save and Test" button, change either the Application name or Application password parameters to invalid ones
- Stash saves it just fine. You will later get the logs below as it tries to sync:

{noformat}
2014-05-07 10:06:57,751 ERROR [scheduler_Worker-7]  c.a.c.d.DbCachingDirectoryPoller Error occurred while refreshing the cache for directory [ 2097154 ].
com.atlassian.crowd.exception.OperationFailedException: com.atlassian.crowd.exception.InvalidAuthenticationException: Application failed to authenticate
...
...
{noformat}

- When you click "Save and Test" Stash should run the tests it did before and don't Save the directory in case the "Application name and/or Application password" are wrong as the user can change those parameters by mistake in the middle of the process.

- _Workaround:_ review the Application name and/or Application password parameters
fields.summary: Possible to save a JIRA User Directory with wrong Application name and/or Application password

fields.description:
Some corporate policies require that users must authenticate using only their AD username/password but build engineering is allowed to use SSH keys.

Create an option to remove individual SSH key access while keeping project/repo access keys.
fields.summary: Restrict SSH access to projects only

fields.description: If the PR is being approved by user who is not on the list of reviewers, Stash should automatically add the user to the list of reviewers. That is because,  without being on the list of reviewers the approval is not shown on pull request list
fields.summary: Anyone approves a PR who is not on the list of reviewers, he/she should be added automatically to the list of reviewers

fields.description:
We use a Gitflow branching strategy.

We do pull requests from a feature into develop, and our testers like the features to be up to date with develop when the assess the pull request.

For example:
- QA tests feature A, and approves
- QA moves on to feature B
- QA would like to be testing features A + B

This flow lets QA test the combinations of new features bit by bit as they go.

We take care of this by running ahead of QA and doing the merges ahead of them. But it would be great if Stash could do these merges automatically.

If there is a better strategy for this, please let me know! We've run into several times features have conflicted with each other, and we like to catch such conflicts before we integrate both into develop.
fields.summary: Upon Acceptance Of A Feature Branch Into Develop, Develop Should Be Automatically Merged Into The Other Feature Branches

fields.description:
*How to reproduce:*
1. Make any Stash repo public
2. Visit your Stash instance unauthenicated
3. Go to the public repositories' page

*Expected behavior:*
A link to the pull request page is displayed and accessible to view pull requests.

*Actual behavior:*
No link displayed; trying to manually access the URL for the pull request overview page redirects to login form.
fields.summary: Allow Anonymous users to view pull requests in public repositories

fields.description:
*How to reproduce:*
1. Make any repo in Stash public
2. Log out, or access Stash unauthenicated in any other way
3. Pull up any file directly through the repo browser or on a commit detail page
4. View the diff to the previous version of the file
5. Switch the default diff style from "Unified diff" to "Side-by-side diff".

*Expected behavior:*
Stash will display the diff in side-by-side style.

*Actual behavior:*
Stash will redirect you to the login form. Attempting to use the back button of your browser gets you back for a split second, then Stash redirects you back to the login form again.
If you try to just click your way through to the file again via the Stash start page link in the navigation bar on top of the page, you will immediately be redirected to the login form again as soon as you pull up any other page with a diff view (obviously Stash sets a cookie with preferred display options). I've even deleted any cookie belonging to the domain I run my Stash instance on in the browser I used to test and still I get redirected. _Update_: You don't even have to pull up a diff view page, you already get redirected if you just try to view the source of a file.
fields.summary: Switching to side-by-side diff continuously redirects anonymous users to login form

fields.description:
Stash binds "Ctrl-Shift-P" to "Preview Comment". This drives me nuts because that's the standard Firefox shortcut for "New Private Browsing Window". Whenever I want to open a new private window for testing something I have to first switch away from Stash.

Stash's keyboard shortcuts should not conflict with default browser shortcuts.

I'm using Firefox 29 on Ubuntu Linux.
fields.summary: Stash binds Ctrl-Shift-P which is a builtin Firefox keyboard shortcut

fields.description:
I first wasn't sure if this was a bug or missing feature, Support confirmed it was the latter (see JSP-191903).
Support suggested that I create the feature request in the Stash project; please move to JIRA if it rather belongs there.

So I have a repo in Stash with the feature branching stuff turned on and configured, and I have set up JIRA integration.
After creating my first issue for a bug, I used the "Create feature branch" link in JIRA's Development Panel to start development on it. I saw the branch was already named with the issue key and summary (e.g. "bugfix/IDC-2-issue-summary-goes-here"), so I committed all my stuff in there without mentioning the issue key again in the commit messages, expecting them to still show up in JIRA's Source Tab because the branch had the issue key in its name – I thought JIRA was "smart" enough to also catch them because of that, which it obviously does not.

Wouldn't it make more sense to treat any commit in such feature branches relevant? Because I think there aren't that many cases in which you'd commit code into a specialized feature branch dedicated to one single JIRA issue that has nothing to do with that feature/linked issue at all. And since programmers are generally lazy, why (remember to!) type the issue key into every single commit message when it's already there, sitting in the branch name where JIRA/Stash could theoretically find it too?
I of course understand that, with a very basic branching scheme where everyone directly commits their stuff to `master`, you'd of course need the key directly in commit messages – but when using `git-flow` and the like (like me in this case here) it really doesn't make any sense at all.

After all it also would add some consistency, given JIRA's "Create feature branch" feature which already prepopulates the branch name field in the form with the issue key per default as well as Stash's specific support for feature branching. Those were the two major points that caused my confusion here leading to the support request - I simply expected JIRA/Stash to work like that because these two features were there.
fields.summary: Show any commits inside a properly named feature branch in that issue's development panel

fields.description:
Hi,

Currently using Basic Authentication on reverse proxies currently bring the "XSRF Security Token Missing" error message. 

_Workaround:_ we have written [a KB|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASHKB/XSRF+Security+Token+Missing]  on this.

This change aims to add supportability to this use case.
fields.summary: Enable XSRF session for sessionless but authenticated requests

fields.description:
Limiting the repository list to 25 when there are only a few more than that causes a number of minor, but noticeable issues:
* A visual delay and interruption when scrolling for just a few more entries
* The possibility of missing that there are more when not completely scrolled (though could trigger earlier to avoid this)
* Limited efficacy of Ctrl-F browser find to locate a project (by name or description) before scrolling

Not all users make a habit of using the repo search for a combination reasons (including preference and also limitations in how it how it works). To that end, the project list should serve its purpose more fully.
fields.summary: Increase the number of repositories initially shown on the repository list from 25 to 100

fields.description: It is useful to be able to filter the list of available projectsinstead of using the quick search, using the browser find or scrolling through pages.
fields.summary: Ability to search or filter project list

fields.description:
From Stash-prod

{noformat}

Unfortunately the stacktrace trimming is too aggressive and I can't see where the issue is actually occurring.
fields.summary: SessionFixationProtection is not handling invalid session correctly

fields.description: Setting permissions for a group within a ProjectPermissionRevokedEvent handler in a plugin does not save the set permission at all. The same API call works correctly during a project create event.
fields.summary: PermissionAdminService API does not grant permissions properly when used in a project permission granted/modified/revoked event

fields.description:
Some of the Jira instances we connect our Stash instance to are sometimes unreachable (due to downtime, network issues etc).

When we attempt to navigate to a Jira issue on the Commits page (i.e. through _/plugins/servlet/jira-integration/issues/jira-id_), we would get a skull error:

Connection lost with _name of Jira instance_

This error message is received irrespective of whether the Jira id in question is hosted on the unreachable Jira environment.  The Jira id in question may actually be hosted on a perfectly reachable Jira instance.

Can this be improved somehow?  For example, in resolving the Jira id visit all Jira instances and remember their reachability and only return the skull error when all instances have been exhausted.  Or, allow projects/repos to have 'preferred' Jira instances to visit first.
fields.summary: Handle unreachable Application Links gracefully when their unreachability is non-critical

fields.description: We have some security/compliance controls in place where not all users have access to the source code. However, these users want to stay informed about commit history. I'm looking for a permission set that would allow someone to "watch" a project/repository, but not actually view or work with the code.
fields.summary: New permission set for watching a repository

fields.description:
Click clone button on Bitbucket and get the following pre-selected text:
git clone git@bitbucket.org:atlassian/crowd.git

Click clone button on Stash and get the following pre-selected text:
git@bitbucket.org:atlassian/crowd.git
fields.summary: Why does Stash not provide git clone as part of the pre-selected clone string like Bitbucket does

fields.description:
This is related to Spring 4.0.0.RELEASE which was introduced in Stash 2.11.0. This only affects newer versions of Java 1.7.0_51 and greater.

https://jira.spring.io/browse/SPR-11335

h2. Diagnose

Taking a thread dump will most likely show many threads being stuck in Spring AOP:

{noformat}
"http-bio-127.0.0.1-7990-exec-5" daemon prio=10 tid=0x00007f510c009800 nid=0x2456 runnable [0x00007f50768e2000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE
    at org.springframework.core.SerializableTypeWrapper$TypeProxyInvocationHandler.invoke(SerializableTypeWrapper.java:220)
    at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy25.equals(Unknown Source)
    at org.springframework.util.ObjectUtils.nullSafeEquals(ObjectUtils.java:252)
    at org.springframework.core.ResolvableType.equals(ResolvableType.java:681)
{noformat}

If profiling is enabled a clear indication is very slow {{getById()}} calls:

{noformat}
[3914ms] - "GET /rest/api/latest/profile/recent/repos HTTP/1.1"
   [1128ms] - Repository com.atlassian.stash.repository.RepositoryService.getById(int)
    [0ms] - Object com.atlassian.stash.internal.Dao.getById(Object)
  [1640ms] - Repository com.atlassian.stash.repository.RepositoryService.getById(int)
    [0ms] - Object com.atlassian.stash.internal.Dao.getById(Object)
  [853ms] - Repository com.atlassian.stash.repository.RepositoryService.getById(int)
    [0ms] - Object com.atlassian.stash.internal.Dao.getById(Object)
{noformat}
fields.summary: Stash performance degrades over time with Java 1.7.0_51

fields.description:
There's something strange going on when I scroll in the diff viewer.

I have my MBP set for "natural scrolling" which is reverse of regular scrolling.

When I scroll slowly in the diff viewer it looks like there's some javascript attempting to scroll in the reverse direction. Slowly scrolling just keeps me at the same point in the page.

Scrolling quicker seems to overcome the javascript, and allows me to scroll in my intended direction.
fields.summary: Diff viewer messing with natural scrolling

fields.description:
*Steps to produce*
# Create new repo.
# Add new file with *over 8000 lines of code*.
# push the file to Stash.
# Open the file in the Source View  within Stash using *IE9*.

*Results*
IE9 will take around 120 and 150 seconds to open file the (the more lines you scroll, the more the refresh will take longer and may seems unresponsive), whereby FF can take 20 and 25 seconds to open the file
fields.summary: Slowness in opening files with 8k+ of lines in the Source View tab within IE9

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update – December 2017|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Bitbucket Server team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-bug-fixing-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication. If you're really passionate about this suggestion, please comment with your case in detail and we'll reconsider. Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Imran Khan
Product Manager - Bitbucket Server and Data Center
{panel}


The Stash/JIA integrations are working quite well for us, but one obvious shortfall is the inability for engineers to log work hours on completion of their work, directly from the Resolve Issue dialog, instead it's a "Edit This in JIRA" link to the JIRA version of of the Resolve Issue, which has more stuff on it.  
(See attached screenshots).

We use Trusted App and OAuth Application Links all round.

This is the only part of the developer side of the workflow that doesn't seem quite right for us.
fields.summary: Ability to Log Work (JIRA) from the Stash "Resolve Issue" page.

fields.description:
We need to work on the repositories dropdown menu.

Basically, it's pretty useless as it is now. 

I suggest the following improvement:  Make the menu hierarchical.

This way we could go to "project" then "repository".  This would not be a huge effort for a good web browser developer making an HTML5 menu...you have all the information you need in the current menu!!!

Furthermore, you could combine the projects and repositories menu into one dropdown menu.  If you install Notifyr, then you would have your favorites menu.  

And...you would eliminate issues regarding the repository menu not being long enough or wide enough for long repository names.

HUGE improvement, and a bug resolution!!!!!
fields.summary: Make the Repository Dropdown menu hierarchical

fields.description:
Currently, the only way to remove a pull request from my inbox is to approve it. This is a usability/productivity problem when I have many pull requests in my inbox, some of which I've already reviewed, but not approved, and others that I've not yet reviewed at all. It can be difficult to find which PRs I have not yet seen.

Other issues (e.g. STASH-2999, STASH-4633) have asked for multiple PR statuses (e.g. complete, disapprove, pending changes). While I support those suggestions, I also see the complexity in creating a design that satisfies many different workflows. I believe that simply decoupling inbox state (in, out) from PR state (not approved, approved), would go a long way to making PRs more manageable, and pose no barrier to more complex solutions in the future.

Regarding design: Imagine an 'x' next to each PR in your inbox. Clicking an 'x' would remove the PR from the inbox (or alternatively gray out the entry). It would return to the inbox when a new commit is pushed. Otherwise, system behavior would remain unchanged (e.g. email alerts with other reviewers' comments would still be sent).

Thanks for a great product. I believe this suggested enhancement is in the spirit of the product's current feature richness delivered through a parsimonious design. I hope you agree.
fields.summary: Decouple inbox from PR approval state

fields.description:
I like the way GitHub does this in their file browser.

There are another two columns which display:
- the beginning of the message attached to the respective file's latest commit (a clickable link that takes you to the commit detail page) and
- the relative date of that latest commit.
For folders, the details of the newest file it contains are taken.

I think this would be a valuable enhancement for Stash.

(Also, from an aesthetic point of view, the file browser currently looks kind of empty only containing short file names but spanning the whole page width :P)
fields.summary: Display last commit title for each file in file browser

fields.description:
The default permission of "Read" does not work when the previous setting was "Write" - if it was "No access", things work fine.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Using an admin account, create a new project
2. First, set the default permission to "Write", then switch to "Read".
3. Try to access the project using a non-admin account.
=> Result: project is not listed, accessing its URL directly results in 401 Unauthorized.
4. Using the admin account, change the project's default permission from "Read" to "No access", then back to "Read".
5. Try to access the project using a non-admin account.
=> Result: project is listed and can be accessed regularly.
fields.summary: Switching default permission from "write" to "read" is broken

fields.description:
The ability to send pull request notifications via HipChat either to a user or to a designated room would be a very useful feature for Stash.  At present email notifications are easy to miss in the flood of other email.  We love the existing Stash integration with HipChat and would love for this feature to be added.  

We are willing to bribe with baked goods or alcoholic beverages should such be requred.
fields.summary: Hipchat Notifications for Pull Requests

fields.description:
Allow administrators to specify a port below 1024 on the external database configuration.

During the external database configuration, the form won't let me put in a port value under 1024 and the following message is displayed:

"Please enter a value between 1024 and 65536"

This configuration should be possible as this is a destination port and Stash should not be concerned about which port the database server is listening on.

Current workaround is to change the db server port to something above 1023.
fields.summary: Allow administrators to specify a port below 1024 on the external database configuration form

fields.description:
{{www.terracottatech.com:80}} and {{org01.terracotta.org:80}} network activities perceived on a Stash instance are due to ehcache (a cache component used in Stash) phoning home for statistics purposes.

These calls should be able to be blacklisted safely by the client on their firewalls without loss of functionality to Stash.

We're checking through this issue whether to completely disable these calls.
fields.summary: Prevent ehcache from phoning home for statistics purposes

fields.description: With a recent upgrade to Stash we gained the ability to comment within commits added to a pull request.  It would also be nice if we could comment on a commit message directly from the overview of the pull request.
fields.summary: Comment on commit messages in pull requests

fields.description:
*Steps to produce*
# Setup Stash with limited users limit (e.g: 10 users).
# Setup JIRA or any user directory and add over 10 users.
# Sync the users to Stash.
# The following warning will appear in the header for *all users*:
{code}
You have more users than your license allows. Pushing is disabled - purchase a license today
{code}
You can see the screenshot as well:
!stash_users.png!


*What to improve*
The wanning message is not really feasible since is shown by all users and can cause some frustration if the admin is not aware of that. Instead, would be feasible to have Stash deducting the user license limit first, warn the admin about the exceeding users limit and let him/her to decide to proceed or not.
fields.summary: If the users exceed the license limit via AD, a warning message should emerge instead of disabling repo push

fields.description:
The new GIT protocol plugin does not clone from user repos:
{code}
aefimov@aefimov-macbook:~/projects/sandbox $ git clone git://stash.acme.com/%7EAEFIMOV/repo.git
Cloning into 'repo'...
fatal: remote error: Invalid repository name '~AEFIMOV/repo.git'.
aefimov@aefimov-macbook:~/projects/sandbox $ git clone git://stash.acme.com/~AEFIMOV/repo.git
Cloning into 'repo'...
fatal: remote error: Invalid repository name '~AEFIMOV/repo.git'.
aefimov@aefimov-macbook:~/projects/sandbox $ git clone git://stash.acme.com/~aefimov/repo.git
Cloning into 'repo'...
fatal: remote error: Invalid repository name '~aefimov/repo.git'.
{code}
fields.summary: git:// protocol does not work for personal repositories
Heavy use of Trusted Apps appears to be causing products to slow

fields.description:
After setting "page.max.directory.children=2500" in {{stash-config.properties}} file, accessing repository have the message "There are too many files in this directory. Only showing the first 500." banner and only 500 files are shown.

Refreshing the same page will show "There are too many files in this directory. Only showing the first 2,500." and 2500 items are listed.
fields.summary: page.max.directory.children does not show correct number of files on page load
Add ability to migrate users from external directory to internal directory

fields.description:
Currently Stash will give the name of the branch as the default pull request title. GitHub Enterprise for example gives the option to have the first commit message to be the title of the pull request.

Please provide this as an option in Stash.
fields.summary: Make it possible to have the first commit in a pull request to be the default title

fields.description:
If a repository has a handful of open pull requests that all merge into master and the master branch is updated it looks like stash will try to update all of the pull request merge branches simultaneously.  With as few as ~30 pull open pull requests this is able to overload the stash server causing very high load (a recent Load Average 15.17 11.90 9.56), and while the interface to stash was responsive other actions were often delayed in being reflected in the web ui (such as updating a branch that was part of a pull request and then going to the pull request page it didnt' say it was updated).  Updating the merge branches shouldn't be able to have this effect.  Some thoughts depending on the implementation could be to:

1) This background task manager shouldn't spawn off more jobs than something like the number of cpus * 2 at any one time.

2) Before starting a job should check if it is already invalid (such as if between when it was started and now if the the master branch has been pushed to causing this job to be pointless as it will be overwritten shortly)

3) Double check the code path that occurs if a merge fails to see if it is more expensive.  In our system we recently had a change to master that caused all pull requests to not be mergeable.  This could very much have just been coincidental.

4) Perhaps only update the merge branch if someone actually visits the pull request webpage or fetches from the pull-request refs

5) double check how the merge operation is being run, perhaps there is a cheaper/faster way to do it.
fields.summary: 10's of pull requests can overload the server

fields.description: With the availability of [HipChat Server|https://www.hipchat.com/server], users will host HipChat in their own servers, while will raise the need to configure the HipChat URL in HipChat Hook within Stash since is using the standard HipChat URL currenlty.
fields.summary: As an admin, I would like to configure my HipChat URL in HipChat Hook

fields.description:
I can't consistently reproduce this, it only happens some of the time and disappears once I refresh the page, but I thought I'd raise the feedback in case I'm not the only one to encounter the issue.

Please see the attached recording - I'm consistently "scrolling" vertically but if you watch the page contents or the scrollbar on the right, you can see occasional "jittering" in the opposite direction to where I'm trying to scroll.

You can see a horizontal scrollbar that flickers in and out of view in the recording, but the behaviour is the same even when there's no horizontal scrollbar (I tested on a larger screen with sufficient width).

I'm scrolling with the trackpad instead of a mouse, using a natural scrolling direction. When I reverse the scrolling direction, the scrolling no longer jitters with the occasional scroll in the wrong direction, but the scrolling isn't smooth - it'll speed up and slow down unexpectedly.
fields.summary: Scrolling while viewing a file in a pull request will occasionally behave unexpectedly

fields.description: We need a way to find the origin of any branch created in stash, since we would like to stop merges of certain branches into release candidates, can you please extend stash to provide this functionality.
fields.summary: Find the origin branch for any given branch

fields.description:
Once a user performs a pull-request, and a reviewer accepts this pull request, yet a second reviewer (or the first reviewer) declines it. The approval status of the reviewers is not reset. 

Atleast the approval status of the person that declined it should be removed.

The result is now, that when a user re-opens a pull request after performing an update, all reviewers are still on approved and do not see the change in their inbox. 

Nor does the pull request state that it was updated by the user by adding N commits.
fields.summary: Pull request - Approve - Decline - Reopen
Customize pullrequests' notifications mail subject

fields.description:
Given this scenario:
LDAP > JIRA User Server > Stash

If the connection to LDAP is lost, when the directory comes back online  the user must have the following data kept:
- global permission
- project permission
- repository permissions
- branch permissions
- avatars
- recently accessed repositories 
- SSH keys

In JIRA, for example, if a user from an external directory has been added to a group and the connection to that external directory is lost, when the directory is activated again, the original user is restored (with their prior group permissions).
fields.summary: Preserve user data upon loss of connection to external user directory

fields.description: Side-by-side diffs currently do not show syntax highlighting. This impedes code reviews in pull requests significantly.
fields.summary: Support syntax highlighting in side-by-side diff

fields.description:
We have a lot of projects (about 60) in our Stash installation, and it would be really great if one could turn off the "load more as you scroll" function, and simply load the entire list at page load. A lot of people seem to just load the front page and CTRL-F to find their projects, which won't work if their projects is not among the top X projects.

As the loading of more projects is super fast, it doesn't seem to pose a performance issues.
fields.summary: Possibility to turn off progressive loading on projects list
Command-f (ctrl-f) on diff pages doesn't scroll to found text in Firefox
File-history dropdown anchors point to latest instead of the correct hash.

fields.description:
It's easy to unintentionally decline a Pull Request, since the hotkey is simply the D key, which is on the homerow of the keyboard. See an anecdote below:

"At the core reviewers meeting today Kat asked why I had declined a PR without offering any comments as to why. What I guess happened is that I had accidentally hit the 'D' key on the keyboard and didn't notice that I'd triggered a decline. It seems I may have done this more than once.

SO, the takeaways are:
If I declined something without a comment, I'm terribly sorry. It wasn't you, it was an accident.
You may also be accidentally triggering Stash actions while your hands rest on your keyboard.
Sorry for any inconvenience caused!"
fields.summary: Accidental Pull Request declines due to ease of hotkey press

fields.description:
I have 2 questions:

When my users commit to a Stash/Git repo using a Jira Issue number for tracking, the commit history only shows up if they write out the Jira Issue number exactly as it is in Jira...for example, FAST-1231. Can we somehow set it up so that this is not case sensitive?

When users create a branch from a Jira issue, the branch gets named after the Issue # and the title of the issue - "feature/IT-14-updating-submodules-to-php4.3" Ovbiously we can delete the "updating-submodules-to-php4.3" postion, but it would be far more ocnvenient if these branches would default to just being named after the Issue # alone. Can that be done?

Let me know, thanks!
fields.summary: Jira Tickets and Stash

fields.description: The option to delete a branch upon merge option randomly disappeared. The checkbox returned upon a restart of the service.
fields.summary: Delete Branch functionality missing

fields.description:
Is there any support for Project-level Users group creation? 

We have an enterprise-wide Stash installation with LDAP, where different groups are creating projects in Stash... Everyone is given a Project Administrator role to manage different repositories... The problem we are facing now is that Users Groups are defined in the Global-level and Project Admins don't have permissions to create users.

As a manager for different projects, with their well-contained list of repositories, I'd like to have ways to create Project-Level Users Groups in addition to the Global one. That way, team leaders can micro-manage user groups per projects... That is, creating individual groups of users with different powers such as those who can push to Master branches (production), while restricting others to only use Develop branch... This should work as the Global level groups, to take advantage of the Branch Permissions capability. 

The current installation at my enterprise environment only gives Project level administration permission to users to manage their own projects. However, administration level permissions are only given to Stash administrators and only those are able to create User Groups...
fields.summary: Project-Level Users Groups (Teams)

fields.description: The API at /rest/api/1.0/projects/XX/repos/YY/commits appears to behave improperly when either the `until` or `since` param can't be resolved. It should probably return a 400. Instead it returns the entire set of commits in the repo's history.
fields.summary: commits REST API returns all commits if `until` or `since` is unknown

fields.description:
It would be nice to be able to retrieve the changes made to a repository in a particular time frame. This should cover the various RepositoryRefChangedEvents:

* pushes
* merged pull requests
* newly created branches

For each of these events, we'd want to record the refs that were modified (ref, from, to) and what user modified these refs
fields.summary: Track and expose changes to repositories over REST

fields.description:
I'm in a pull request and using the side-by-side diff, ignore whitespace is on too btw.
If I add a comment the comment box is overflowing and being hidden, I have to scroll to hit the comment or cancel button.

Once the comment has been saved the comment is also hidden in the overflow.

FYI: I can't upload a screenshot at the moment, it returns an error 500.
fields.summary: Comments in side-by-side diff overflow

fields.description: When moving through pull requests and a merge conflict comes up sometimes it is just a matter of resolving everything to the newer version. i would be nice to have this option from the GUI, or to be able to edit simple conflicts.
fields.summary: Resolve Merge Conflicts from the UI

fields.description:
Integration tests won't work in Stash 2.12.1.

I created a dummy plugin using command *atlas-create-stash-plugin*. No code or settings were changed. After that I tried to run integration tests on it using *atlas-integration-test*, but it failed to work properly with such log output: http://pastebin.com/6d1Rywvs

By default the plugin utilize atlassian-plugins-osgi-testrunner version 1.1.4 and the above log file was generated with it.
I was advised to use the newer version of testrunner in which problems with test launch were hopefully solved. So I changed parameter *plugin.testrunner.version* in POM to 1.2.0 and tried *atlas-integration-test* again. But I am still unlucky with this log output: http://pastebin.com/Z59ZD4q4

It seems like integration tests are broken from version 2.5.0 of Stash and since Stash source doesn't use them for its testing it remains still unattended.
fields.summary: Integration tests not working in Stash

fields.description: Currently, markdown tables rendered in Stash do not contain any sort of border. Depending on the table's content it can be hard to read without any borders. It would be very helpful if a thin border would be rendered around the table and/or table cells.
fields.summary: Render markdown tables with a border
Sort "Recently viewed" repository drop-down list by last visited, not alphabetically
Markdown render fails on anchor tag

fields.description:
In Safari 7 on Mavericks, loading a diff longer than can be displayed breaks scrolling.

e.g. URL will be something like:
http://stash.domain.example./projects/PROJECT/repos/project/pull-requests/1/diff
or:
http://stash.domain.example./projects/PROJECT/repos/project/commits/h4sh#file.name

The scroll bar will appear as you try to scroll, but the bottom of the file never moves into view. Disabling javascript does not fix the issue (you seem to have forgotten the mantra of "progressive enhancement").

Works as expected in Chrome 34, though I wouldn't call being told to use a different browser a work-around, hence I have made this a Major issue.
fields.summary: Diff does not scroll in Safari 7

fields.description:
Here we go...

I had two users. One from internal database with email address "xyz@domain.com" and the other was from Crowd with the same email address "xyz@domain.com".

Internal database was priority #1 in the list when going through users and Crowd was #1 for authentication users.

I committed my code and browsed to it. Even though I committed it under the Crowd user it showed for that file and that commit it was done by the internal user. Once I changed the email of the internal user, it matched up to the correct user.

Now I know what your saying "two accounts with the same password?" But yes, that could happen with Crowd and other factors. It might not be a stash issue. Could be a User Directory issue, but I have no seen that error come up on any other product _or_ you are going to say "Won't Fix" because why would you have the internal admin account as the same email address as a user?

Just so you know, totally minor. Trivial in fact.
fields.summary: Same email address for the user, shows commit as wrong user

fields.description:
Not sure if Chromium is a supported platform as well as Chrome.  If not please close this, but as the two are related it may show up on chrome as well.

Since we upgraded Stash from 2.10 to 2.12 some of our users are now reporting the diff view is truncated on the right.  This happens in both unified and side-by-side.  Attached screen-shot shows the issue.
fields.summary: Diff view rendering issue on Chromium
